content.rendered:
Observed the last Monday of May and first known as Dedication Day, Memorial Day was established in 1868 to honor Union Soldiers who had died in the American Civil War. Now, it not only honors those Union soldiers, but all US soldiers who have died in armed conflict.

The holiday is celebrated both nationally and on the state level by decorating graves. Many individuals place flowers or wreaths on the graves of loved ones who they have lost. At the federal level, special recognition is given at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. There’s also a National Memorial Day Concert, which airs on PBS.

Ecclesiastes 3:1-4 (KJV) tells us that, “To every thing there is a season, and a time to every purpose under the heaven: A time to be born, and a time to die; a time to plant, and a time to pluck up that which is planted; A time to kill, and a time to heal; a time to break down, and a time to build up; A time to weep, and a time to laugh; a time to mourn, and a time to dance.”

As a nation, this is our time to morn, and to remember the sacrifice that many have made for the sake of their country.
